cluster_relations.rel_desc: The austenitic structure is normally found in 300 Series austenitic stainless steels.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: AlloyScope: 300 Series stainless steels

remarks: Complements the alloy→structure relation by capturing where the structure is typically present.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Ferritic structure occurs as one phase within duplex stainless steels.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: StructureContext: part of mixed austenitic-ferritic phase balance

remarks: Redundant with the duplex→ferritic structural relation but captures the inverse perspective (where ferritic is found).

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Austenitic structure occurs as one phase within duplex stainless steels.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: StructureContext: part of mixed austenitic-ferritic phase balance

remarks: Inverse perspective of the duplex→austenitic structural relation, included for coverage of where the austenitic phase is found.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Hydrogen Induced Cracking (HIC) is described as a cracking mechanism that occurs in steels, which plausibly includes low alloy steels as a subset.

qualifiers.SpatialQualifier: on different planes in the metal / steels; may connect to the metal surface
qualifiers.OperationalConstraint: no externally applied stress is needed for formation of HIC
qualifiers.CausalHint: because of internal pressure resulting from the accumulation of hydrogen
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: CrackMechanism: stepwise internal cracks that connect adjacent hydrogen blisters; LinkMechanism: transgranular plastic shear

remarks: Relation added mainly to capture that HIC is a cracking mechanism relevant to steels, with low alloy steel treated as a representative steel family. Semantics somewhat generic; confidence reduced because the text does not explicitly name low alloy steels as HIC-susceptible.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Graphitization occurs in low alloy C-Mo steels containing up to 1% Mo.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: ObservationContext: field or service experience

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Graphite nodules are present in carbon steels as products of carbide decomposition at elevated temperatures.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Origin: decomposition of carbide phases

remarks: Subjective mapping of the pronoun “these steels” to carbon steels; 0.5Mo steels are handled in a separate relation.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Graphite nodules can also occur in 0.5Mo steels under elevated temperature conditions.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Origin: carbide phase decomposition associated with graphitization

remarks: Moderate uncertainty because the pronoun could be read as all previously mentioned affected steels.

args.canonical_rel_desc: The subject phase, microstructural feature, damage mechanism, or process occurs within or in association with the object material or alloy, which serves as its host environment.
args.justification: All these relations express that a structure, process, or damage mechanism (e.g., austenitic/ferritic phase, HIC, graphitization, graphite nodules) occurs within or in the context of a particular steel or alloy family. They share the same directional predicate semantics: the subject phenomenon is present in or hosted by the object material.
args.remark: Kept the canonical predicate as 'occurs_in' and generalized its description so it can uniformly apply to microstructures, degradation processes, and cracking mechanisms in steels.

args.justification: Each relation links a material-hosting alloy or steel to a phenomenon (microstructure, degradation product, or cracking mechanism) that occurs within it. This forms a coherent family distinct from composition or causal relations: it captures where a phenomenon manifests in terms of material context.

The core semantics is that the subject occurs within or is hosted by the object material, i.e., a spatial or host-environment containment relation between phenomenon and material, rather than a purely causal or compositional link.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: The subject phase, microstructural feature, damage mechanism, or process occurs within or in association with the object material or alloy, which serves as its host environment.
executed_decisions.justification: All these relations express that a structure, process, or damage mechanism (e.g., austenitic/ferritic phase, HIC, graphitization, graphite nodules) occurs within or in the context of a particular steel or alloy family. They share the same directional predicate semantics: the subject phenomenon is present in or hosted by the object material.
executed_decisions.remark: Kept the canonical predicate as 'occurs_in' and generalized its description so it can uniformly apply to microstructures, degradation processes, and cracking mechanisms in steels.

executed_decisions.justification: Each relation links a material-hosting alloy or steel to a phenomenon (microstructure, degradation product, or cracking mechanism) that occurs within it. This forms a coherent family distinct from composition or causal relations: it captures where a phenomenon manifests in terms of material context.

The core semantics is that the subject occurs within or is hosted by the object material, i.e., a spatial or host-environment containment relation between phenomenon and material, rather than a purely causal or compositional link.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Stainless steels are resistant to oxidation due to their alloy content.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: MechanismType: corrosion mechanism

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Stainless steels are resistant to sulfidation due to their alloy content.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: MechanismType: corrosion mechanism

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Stainless steels resist various forms of general corrosion, beyond just oxidation and sulfidation, depending on alloy content.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Scope: other forms of corrosion beyond oxidation and sulfidation

remarks: Relation generalized from phrase 'other forms of corrosion' to entity 'general corrosion'.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Chromium, as an alloying element in stainless steels, contributes to resistance against oxidation.

qualifiers.ConditionExpression: when present as alloying element in stainless steels
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Context: chromium in stainless steel alloy matrix

remarks: Resistance is mediated via stainless steels; not direct chromium surface behavior, but captured as a causal contribution.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Chromium, as an alloying element in stainless steels, contributes to resistance against sulfidation.

qualifiers.ConditionExpression: when present as alloying element in stainless steels
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Context: chromium in stainless steel alloy matrix

remarks: Again, resistance is via its role in stainless steels rather than isolated chromium behavior.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Chromium contributes to resistance to general corrosion forms when used as an alloying element in stainless steels.

qualifiers.ConditionExpression: when present as alloying element in stainless steels; depending on the alloy content
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Scope: general corrosion (other forms of corrosion)

remarks: Relation created mainly to capture that chromium helps overall corrosion resistance; semantics slightly generalized.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Adding approximately 0.7% chromium to low alloy C-Mo steels eliminates graphitization.

qualifiers.ConditionExpression: addition of about 0.7% chromium; steels with up to 1% Mo

remarks: Material context (low alloy C-Mo steels with up to 1% Mo) added as qualifiers rather than as extra entities.

args.canonical_rel_desc: The subject material exhibits resistance to the specified corrosion mechanism under stated conditions.
args.justification: All three relations link 'Stainless Steel' to specific corrosion mechanisms (oxidation, sulfidation, general corrosion) and describe the material's resistance to those mechanisms, not its causal contribution to another material. They share the same predicate semantics of a material resisting a corrosion mechanism.

args.canonical_rel_desc: The subject alloying element contributes causally to the resistance of an alloy or material against the specified corrosion mechanism.
args.justification: These three relations consistently describe chromium, as an alloying element in stainless steels, causally contributing to resistance against oxidation, sulfidation, and general corrosion. The semantics are that the element provides or enhances resistance, rather than directly resisting as a bulk material.
args.remark: Although resistance manifests in the stainless steel, the modeled predicate focuses on chromium's causal contribution to that resistance.

args.canonical_rel_desc: The subject inhibits or effectively eliminates the occurrence of the specified degradation process under the given conditions.
args.justification: This relation states that adding about 0.7% chromium to low alloy C-Mo steels eliminates graphitization. The natural predicate is that chromium prevents (inhibits) the graphitization process under the described compositional context.

All six relations concern how materials or alloying elements relate to corrosion mechanisms in terms of resistance (either directly resisting corrosion or providing resistance to it). Grouping them under a corrosion_resistance_relation class captures this shared thematic focus.
args.remark: Within this class, there are two predicate-level patterns: bulk material resisting a mechanism and alloying element providing resistance to that mechanism.

args.justification: The relation describes chromium inhibiting or eliminating a metallurgical degradation process (graphitization) in low alloy steels, fitting a broader class of relations where a substance inhibits or suppresses degradation phenomena.

These relations encode how a material (stainless steel) interacts with corrosion mechanisms in terms of resistance. They are best viewed as an interaction between material and environment (corrosion mechanism), rather than a separate causal agent modifying another system.

These relations describe chromium's causal role: as an alloying element it provides resistance to corrosion mechanisms and prevents graphitization. The semantics center on chromium causing improved resistance or elimination of a degradation process, so a causal group is appropriate.

executed_decisions.justification: All three relations link 'Stainless Steel' to specific corrosion mechanisms (oxidation, sulfidation, general corrosion) and describe the material's resistance to those mechanisms, not its causal contribution to another material. They share the same predicate semantics of a material resisting a corrosion mechanism.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Graphitization alters the microstructure of carbon steels after long-term operation, degrading their mechanical properties.

qualifiers.OperationalConstraint: operation in the 800°F to 1100°F (427°C to 593°C) range
qualifiers.CausalHint: that may cause a loss in strength, ductility, and/or creep resistance
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: DamageType: mechanical property degradation

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Graphitization alters the microstructure of 0.5Mo steels during long-term high-temperature operation.

qualifiers.OperationalConstraint: operation in the 800°F to 1100°F (427°C to 593°C) range
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: DamageType: loss in strength, ductility, and/or creep resistance

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Graphitization corresponds to decomposition of carbide phases into graphite nodules, effectively producing graphite nodules in the steel.
remarks: Carbide phases are not an explicit entity; relation framed between graphitization and graphite nodules to preserve transformation context.

args.canonical_rel_desc: A process changes or modifies the microstructure of a material, without specifying the exact product phases formed.
args.justification: Both relations describe graphitization changing the microstructure of susceptible steels during long-term high-temperature operation. The semantic focus is microstructural alteration of the steel, not explicitly the product phase. A normalized predicate 'modifies_microstructure_of' captures this consistently.
args.remark: Normalized from the more specific wording 'alters_microstructure_of' to a reusable predicate.

args.canonical_rel_desc: A process leads to the formation or production of a specific microstructural feature or phase in a material.
args.justification: This relation expresses that graphitization decomposes carbide phases and results in graphite nodules. The key semantics are that the process produces a particular microstructural feature, which is well captured by 'produces_microstructural_feature'.
args.remark: More specific than a generic 'produces' predicate, indicating microstructural products.

args.justification: All three relations involve graphitization as a metallurgical degradation process that changes steel microstructure, either by modifying the bulk microstructure or producing graphite nodules. They belong to the same broader family of microstructural transformation/degradation relations.

Each relation describes a process modifying the state of a material: altering its microstructure or producing new microstructural features. This fits the broad category of state/structure modification rather than pure composition or identity.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: A process changes or modifies the microstructure of a material, without specifying the exact product phases formed.
executed_decisions.justification: Both relations describe graphitization changing the microstructure of susceptible steels during long-term high-temperature operation. The semantic focus is microstructural alteration of the steel, not explicitly the product phase. A normalized predicate 'modifies_microstructure_of' captures this consistently.
executed_decisions.remark: Normalized from the more specific wording 'alters_microstructure_of' to a reusable predicate.

executed_decisions.remark: More specific than a generic 'produces' predicate, indicating microstructural products.

They belong to the same broader family of microstructural transformation/degradation relations.

Each relation describes a process modifying the state of a material: altering its microstructure or producing new microstructural features. This fits the broad category of state/structure modification rather than pure composition or identity.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Methyldiethanolamine and monoethanolamine are both used in amine treating to remove H2S and CO2 from hydrocarbon streams, indicating they serve similar functional roles and can be alternatives to each other.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: ApplicationContext: amine treating of hydrocarbon streams for H2S and CO2 removal

remarks: Relation created to capture that these two amine treating chemicals share the same described use; semantics are approximated as an alternative/substitute relation since no explicit comparison wording is given.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Duplex stainless steel is one of the four categories of stainless steels listed.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: CategoryType: stainless steel category

remarks: Although text just says 'duplex', entity is resolved as duplex stainless steel; relation captures the category membership.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Duplex stainless steel is a subtype/category within the broader class of stainless steels.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that two materials or chemicals can be used interchangeably or as substitutes for the same technical function in a given application context.
args.justification: The relation connects two amine treating chemicals used for the same functional purpose (removal of H2S and CO2 from hydrocarbon streams). The semantics are that one can serve as an alternative/substitute for the other in this application, which is best captured as a functional alternative relation.
This relation describes that two process chemicals can substitute for each other in the same functional role, which is a type of functional substitution rather than composition or taxonomy.
The core semantics are about how the chemicals are used (interchangeably for the same treatment function) rather than their composition or identity, fitting a broad usage/application dimension.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a broader class or category includes the specified subtype or subclass as a member.
args.justification: The subject is the broad class (Stainless Steel) and the object is one of its categories (duplex stainless steel). This is a parent-to-child taxonomic relation, best normalized as 'has_subtype' rather than the looser 'has_category'.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject is a more specific subtype or subclass within the broader class represented by the object.
args.justification: The subject (duplex stainless steel) is described as belonging to the broader category of stainless steels. This is the child-to-parent direction of the same taxonomic hierarchy and should be represented as 'is_subtype_of'.

Both relations express hierarchical classification between a general material class (Stainless Steel) and a specific subclass (duplex stainless steel), one in the parent-to-child direction and the other in child-to-parent. They belong to the same family of material taxonomy relations.

Taxonomic subtype relations describe hierarchical identity/isa relationships (what kind of thing something is) rather than composition, usage, or causality, so they belong under a broad identity/classification dimension.

The core semantics are about how the chemicals are used (interchangeably for the same treatment function) rather than their composition or identity, fitting a broad usage/application dimension.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Mechanical and Metallurgical Failure and Uniform or Localized Loss of Thickness are presented as peer sections within the same list of damage mechanisms.
cluster_relations.object_entity_name: Uniform or Localized Loss of Thickness

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: DocumentStructure: listed as peer damage mechanism categories in the same section

remarks: Relation reflects document-level grouping rather than a causal or hierarchical dependency; direction is arbitrary and used only to encode co-membership.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Uniform or Localized Loss of Thickness and High Temperature Corrosion are presented as peer sections within the same list of damage mechanisms.
cluster_relations.subject_entity_name: Uniform or Localized Loss of Thickness

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: DocumentStructure: co-listed as damage mechanism categories

remarks: Relation mainly encodes co-membership in the same list; not implying any causal or structural dependency between the mechanisms.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: High Temperature Corrosion and Environment Assisted Cracking are presented as peer sections within the same list of damage mechanisms.
cluster_relations.object_class_label: Stress Corrosion and Environment Assisted Cracking Mechanisms

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: DocumentStructure: both are subsections under the same damage mechanisms section

remarks: Relation created to capture that both mechanisms are co-classified in the same document section; direction is arbitrary.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that two entities are presented or classified together as peer categories within the same document section or list, without implying causal, hierarchical, or compositional dependence. The relation is symmetric and direction is arbitrary.
args.justification: All three relations explicitly describe co-listed, peer damage mechanism categories within the same document section or list, with remarks noting that direction is arbitrary and the semantics are document-level grouping rather than causal or hierarchical. They share identical predicate meaning (document-based co-grouping), so they should use a single symmetric canonical predicate 'grouped_with'.
args.remark: Normalized these co-classification edges to a symmetric document-grouping predicate for consistent KG usage.

args.justification: Each relation connects damage mechanism categories that are co-listed as peer sections or subsections in the same document, with qualifiers and remarks emphasizing document structure and co-classification. This fits a dedicated class for document-based co-classification/grouping rather than causal, hierarchical, or compositional relations.
args.remark: Class captures generic document-structure-based grouping used for peer categories, especially damage mechanisms.

args.justification: The relations encode that mechanisms are co-presented or co-classified in the same document context, which is a non-causal, non-hierarchical associative link. This is best captured as an ASSOCIATION-type group.
args.remark: Explicitly marked as ASSOCIATION to distinguish these from causal, compositional, or taxonomic edges in the KG.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Austenitic stainless steels are characterized by an austenitic metallurgical structure.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: AlloyScope: 300 Series stainless steels including Types 304, 304L, 304H, 309, 310, 316, 316L, 316H, 321, 321H, 347, and 347H

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: StructureType: mixed austenitic-ferritic

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Duplex stainless steels have a ferritic component in their mixed austenitic-ferritic structure.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: StructureType: mixed austenitic-ferritic

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that an alloy or steel grade possesses a particular metallurgical/microstructural phase or structure (e.g., austenitic, ferritic, martensitic) under specified conditions.
args.justification: All relations link a stainless steel type or category to a specific metallurgical phase or structure (austenitic, ferritic, martensitic) as a defining microstructural characteristic, often with qualifiers like room temperature or mixed structure; they are semantically identical and can share one canonical predicate.

Each relation expresses a link between an alloy/steel grade and its microstructural/metallurgical phase (austenitic, ferritic, martensitic), which is a specific type of structure-related relation best grouped under a microstructure-focused class.
The semantics center on the structural/microstructural nature of the materials (their metallurgical structure), not composition, causality, or usage; thus they belong to a broad structural group.

executed_decisions.justification: All relations link a stainless steel type or category to a specific metallurgical phase or structure (austenitic, ferritic, martensitic) as a defining microstructural characteristic, often with qualifiers like room temperature or mixed structure; they are semantically identical and can share one canonical predicate.

Each relation expresses a link between an alloy/steel grade and its microstructural/metallurgical phase (austenitic, ferritic, martensitic), which is a specific type of structure-related relation best grouped under a microstructure-focused class.
The semantics center on the structural/microstructural nature of the materials (their metallurgical structure), not composition, causality, or usage; thus they belong to a broad structural group.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Welds of austenitic stainless steels may exhibit a duplex-type (austenitic-ferritic) structure, linking them conceptually to duplex stainless steels.

qualifiers.SpatialQualifier: in welds of 300 Series stainless steels
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: MicrostructureContext: weld metal/heat-affected zone duplex (austenitic-ferritic) structure

remarks: Relation created mainly to capture that welds of austenitic stainless steels can show a duplex (austenitic-ferritic) microstructure; semantic mapping to the duplex stainless steel family is approximate.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Stainless steels contain varying amounts of chromium as an alloying element.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: CompositionContext: alloy content in stainless steels

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject material exhibits a microstructural state that is similar to or analogous to that of the object material, without implying strict identity of composition or grade.
args.justification: The description states that welds of austenitic stainless steels may exhibit a duplex (austenitic-ferritic) structure, conceptually linking them to duplex stainless steels via similarity of microstructure rather than identity or composition. A predicate emphasizing microstructural similarity best captures this semantics.
args.remark: This relation captures a conceptual microstructural analogy between austenitic stainless steel welds and duplex stainless steels, not strict grade equivalence.

args.justification: The link is based on both materials exhibiting a duplex (austenitic-ferritic) structure in certain regions (weld metal/HAZ). This is fundamentally about microstructural characteristics, so a microstructure-focused relation class is appropriate.

The relation expresses a conceptual association via similar microstructure between two alloy families; it does not assert compositional containment, causality, or hierarchy, but rather a structural analogy. This fits best under a broad ASSOCIATION group.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject alloy contains the object chemical element as an intentional alloying constituent in its composition.
args.justification: The relation explicitly states that stainless steels contain chromium as an alloying element. The existing raw relation_name already matches this semantics well and can be adopted as the normalized canonical predicate.

The subject is an alloy class (stainless steel) and the object is a chemical element (chromium) present as an alloying addition. This is a prototypical alloying-element composition relation, so a specific class for alloying element links is appropriate.
The relation concerns which element is contained within the alloy, i.e., the compositional makeup of stainless steel. This clearly falls under a broad COMPOSITION group.
